reviewText:
Okay...let's get the bad and the ugly out of the way first.
Support for this game has been dropped entirely as of a few years ago. There's a few bugs that won't ever be fixed. As far as I know, the community is mostly dead. It's a pain in the rear to get started sometimes, and that seems to depend entirely on the alignment of the planets in relation to Will Wright's left buttock.
That said, when this truly wonderful game decides to work, it's really. freaking. fun.
You can make your own bizzare alien creatures, put stupid hats on them, build them spaceships to whiz around in, and blow stuff up. Including Earth.
You can make friends with, or eat, pretty damn near any creature you encounter in the first two-fifths of the game, and then start forming a society. Which can also be founded on either making friends, slaughtering enemies, or both. You then go on to play a simplified version of Sid Meier's Civilization, in which you get to make your own units, control the spice (AND THE UNIVERSE...no, that's later), and take over the world. After which, you can conquer the galaxy however you wish. Do you want to make friends with whatever alien races you encounter? Go right ahead! Is blowing them up and taking their stuff more your style? You can do that, too! Would you prefer to subvert your enemies through the power of capitalism, and buy their homeworlds RIGHT OUT FROM UNDER THEM? HECK YEAH!
Also there's some minor stuff about reaching the galactic core or whatever, but that doesn't matter much.
You can also visit alien worlds and go on exciting adventures created by other players.
Or you could spend endless hours creating things yourself.
Anyway, THIS GAME IS AMAZING YOU NEED IT

reviewText:
Galactic Adventures adds missions for your space captain during the final stage of Spore. Previously during this stage you were mostly restricted to being a spaceship - which is kinda weird when you've spent so much time careful crafting the creatures that you're playing with and this was meant to address that.

On the plus side, it is nice to be able to play your creatures again and it does even potentially give you the ability to earn the super powers from the other factions (for example you could be militarily based, but earn a shaman super power) rather than just being restricted to one and some of the missions are kinda fun, although there is often a quite heavy focus on combat which is still not great and you don't have any equips for initially.

The down side though... It was a bit of a half arsed attempted by Maxis to cash in on user content and the amount of missions actually included with it by default seems to be rather small. Places will send you off to do a mission and when you arrive there you'll find it's a mission you have already played. Now at this point you can only progress by completing it again, but because you've already done it once you won't receive any experience for it. This won't stop other planets sending you on this mission again and again though. Player created content is frequently dross and the filtering system is largely unintuitive making it very hard to make sure you actually get any decent adventures.

Each adventure also eats a planet. Did that planet have an expensive spice on it? Too bad. Is it contantly sending out signals to tell you there is a rare hidden there? Too bad. Once it's an adventure mission, even if it's a duplicate, it will sit there cutting off access to that planet forever. Since planets tend to generate them in nearby systems this can result in areas, especially around your starting systems becoming cluttered with unusable mission planets.

Galactic Adventures is a great idea that was badly implemented and promptly dropped by the studio rather than being fixed. Whilst it definitely adds some much needed creature time to the space stage I don't feel it adds enough longevity to actually be worth it. If you already have Spore, pick it up during a sale if it goes decently low.

reviewText:
Gave a bad review for Spore, going to give another, different opinion on Galactic Adventures.

Reinstalled it awhile ago so that when I had relatives (children) visiting they would have something to play that wasn't A) age inappropriate and B) wouldn't ask me questions or have me complete a stage/quest/enemy every five minutes.  I don't mind helping but when a kid is basically having you play the entire game for them, that game is not for them.  Said kids were absolutely delighted by Spore and I realized what my issue with it was in the first place.

Simply put, this is a game that doesn't know who it's target audience is.  Or maybe I misinterpreted who it's demographic is and said hey, you can make stuff, this game is for me.

Spore / Galactic Adventures, is, a great game for kids (with some exceptions)... It's cartoony, whimsical, and they can flex their imaginations with the creature creation.  However, there are a few principles that a very young child will have difficulty grasping.  My neighbor's kid (a seven year old) loved the tide pool and loved the animal stage but once he got to the civilization stage it went south real fast.  So maybe nine or ten is the ideal age here.

That said, there is some absolute talent behind some of the player made creatures/vehicles etc and I'm going to take a guess that those folks are adults.  I had fun with the creation aspect of the game too.  This is where the game has it's identity crisis for me.  Some of it is appealing to adults, some of it is childish, but the whole of it appeals to neither at the same time.  Finally, the concept itself is a novel idea and one that I hope can be refined some day- in a different game.

Once that novelty has worn off, all that's left is a tedious cycle of traveling between planets, trading spice (literally the only thing you get to trade), looking at butt ugly creatures my neighbor's kid made (sorry, kiddo!), running home to defend against raiders, and terraforming- things that sound exciting at first and are exciting at first, and then get promptly beaten with a tediousness stick.

reviewText:
Spore had originally promised to be something that sounded truly amazing, A cartoony journey of discovery of an entire species. However the end result is a short little jaunt as you collect whatever type of points you want as you slowly shape your creature to its final space-stage civilization. Sadly it doesn't really matter all that much for most of your decisions. Only one background isn't obtainable if you just make what you want and skip straight to later stages. It doesn't feel like a journey, more like an investment of time for an early space stage jumpstart. Needless to say that many where disapointed.

There is a bit of unnaturalness in how creatures move, and some polish would have been nice for bipeds and the way their torsos bounce up and down like yoyos. It would be nice if the servers where better, and wheren't filled with garbage creatuers. If Steam can ever set up their own Spore server it would a tremendous boon all in all.

All the problems can be attributed to EA who distributed the game, pushing for earlier release, and cutting content just to sell it back to you later in EA style expansion packs. (I have a lot of personal issues with many of EA's policies.)

However all its negative parts aside really is a good game. Spending a lot more time making your race exactly the way you want it to be can be satisfying as you hunt down parts in the creature stage. The stages are well balanced for difficulty, and it's one of the few games you can playthrough and get stronger without actually killing anything. Something i always thought was an interesting design concept.

reviewText:
This it not another review of unfulfilled promises, because I was VERY late to the party so I have no idea what those promises were supposed to BE.

I tried really hard to like this game, but it essentially punished me the entire time I was playing it.  I don't care that the multiplayer servers have been shut down, it's just not a very good game.  Never in my life have I seen a game that was centered totally on sandboxy crafting that simultaneously made it obnoxiously and irrationally difficult to do so.

Graphics are terrible, sounds are okay if you don't mind public domain animal noises.

The game is divided into five stages:  Cell, creature, tribal, civilization, and space.

As a small organism you eat bits of meat, other creatures, or plant particles in order to increase your DNA.  You get bigger, break into a larger aquatic biome, and do it again.  This stage is actually very quick, unless you want to be an omnivore, in which case you need the ONE mouth part that enables that behavior, and spend some time grinding whatever you haven't been eating.

The creature stage by far takes the longest.  This is the major developmental stage for your creatures, and all the parts are earned here.  The stage is basically nests of neutral creatures, nests of creatures that attack on sight, giant creatures you have almost no hope of defeating, bones to pick DNA parts from, and fruit.  So you make friends with other species or eat them, and tweak your creature's physiology as this is your last chance to do so.

Many of the creature parts are purely cosmetic.  The ones that actually raise stats may not play nice with the other parts in terms of clipping or alignment.  I assume every creature was made with the in-game editor, and that I must be terribly bad at it since all my creatures looked like walking potatoes.  Hell, the first two races I made weren't even upright, the game is actually somewhat terrible at telling you these things.

Side note:  who puts wings in a game like this and doesn't technically enable flying?  You flap, you glide.  Your AI pack members go higher than you - always, as if to mock you.  The game was designed this way.  What the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•?

The tribal stage consists of half a dozen major tribes that arise from the masses of creatures.  You're given roughly 12 buildings/techs/instruments with which to make friends or destroy your enemies.  Again.

The civilization stage you finally get a proper city.  You can eventually have land, air, and sea vehicles.  One of each type.  You can design four buildings, including the city hall.  That's it.  AI is predictable, it's not even Civilization Lite.

The space stage held lots of promises of being really deep and cool, but honestly I only made it there once. I read later that there wasn't actually a lot of content for this stage, they were hoping people would make the bulk of the missions for them.   The whole game is a disappointing slog.

My tally:

1st race:  Didn't know what I was doing.  Three hours into the game, it crashed.  I heard later that the game has a problem running on newer hardware.  Since Maxis FORGOT HOW TO PROGRAM AN AUTOSAVE, my entire race and progress was gone.

2nd race:  I created an omnivore.  Or tried.  I made it to the creature stage, discovered I wasn't getting any of the appropriate mouth-parts.  Checked online, learned that to become an omnivore you have to do this in the CELLULAR stage, or not at all.

3rd race:  I made the Krogan from Mass Effect.  Murdered everything in sight.  The civilization stage felt restrictive and obnoxiously difficult somehow, though dropping nukes was fun.  I actually made it to the space stage, and I got this feeling that there would be quite a bit more cool stuff if I wasn't slaughtering everything.  This restart's on me.

4th race:  I made a true omnivore, got up to the creature stage.  Befriended everyone I could, enemies that attacked me became extinct.  Advanced to the tribal stage, discovered the game had classified me as a predator.  I'm sorry what?  So I reloaded, and spent the next TWO HOURS befriending THIRTY SPECIES, watching the same literal song and dance routines over.. and over.. and OVER again.  Advanced to the tribal stage, discovered I was now in the MIDDLE of the predator rating instead of buried in the deep end.

From this, I infer that I would have to spend another two hours and befriend another thirty species to touch middle-road".  I don't even think that many species can be on the planet.  I've also read somewhere that the parts you have equipped may adversely affect your alignment
date: so literally the ONLY THING the game has going for it still works against you.  No thanks."

I don't know if I can recconmend the DLC or not but just for how many Negatives I'm going to add in this Reivew I'll just make it a not recconmended reiview.
The upsides are this DLC gives you the power to make adventures in a world similar to the Creature stage, You can also use the things you used in combat as a creature and the things you used to socialize.

If you want to make an adventure you'll have to put alot of effort into it if you want everybody to like it, Which is a bad thing if you haven't got the time.

TL;DR version: Upsides: A whole new way of playing Space Stage and the Ability to make adventures to entertain other users.
Downsides: There's going to be alot of trash and I mean alot of trash, Not ALL adventures will be compatible with certain creatures so keep that in mind if your creature cannot fly or jump, You'll have to put some effort into an adventure if you want others to enjoy it, Which is a downside for people that are too busy.

reviewText:
The concept of the game isn't bad- in fact, I quite enjoyed designing my creatures in the early stages (they turned out as winged, bideal tigers).

The gameplay itself however, is quite boring and linear. You start as a micro-organism, then go to dry land, and eventually become sapient at which point you stop evolving your creature and enter the tribal, modern, and space age.

While the first few stages involve a bit of exploration and you can assemble a small pack to follow you around, tribal and modern periods play like an extremely simple and dull RTS game. I found space the UI of the space exploration stage to be extremely unwieldly, and combat clumsy and unsatisfying.

As much fun and potential as there is in designing your species, your buildings, and all your vehicles, all that effort is wasted in the gameplay itself where very little is affected.

Additionally, the DRM was a hassle and despite numerous attempts, I was unable to sync my game to the Spore servers, leaving me with only the default creatures to populate my game.

While perhaps not a bad way to spend an afternoon, I doubt there's any replay value to be found here.

reviewText:
This game, and its companion Galactic Adventures, are fantastic.   I cannot, however, recommend the game.

The reason i cannot do so is because EA does not properly support this product, from what I can tell.   Upon installing and running the first time, I was prompted to connect to my EA account.  That was simple enough.  The problem, however, is that the servers which handled authentication apparently were shut off some time ago,so you can't properly authenticate the game.    You'll get an error saying the code doesn't work, and if you try to use the CD key, it will say it is not valid.

I tried a workaround by logging into EA's site and binding the key there, but that also doesnt' work.   It says it successfully bound to the account but doesn't connect in Steam. Contact with EA support is what gave me the information I've stated above.   The only thing I haven't tried is downloading Origin (security holes from what I've seen, so no) and then using that to obtain Spore via my linked account, separating it from Steam.

This game is entirely playable without registration, but there is no access to the creations of other players, which was a major benefit to Galactic Adventures (since it has a mission builder) as well as being able to reach new creatures for Spore that others created.

I would wager this will also cause problems with downloading DLC and entering codes to activate it, as seems to be a major complaint on forums regarding this game.

The workaround is to call EA support (not email or online chat) and bounce through extensions until you get to someone who can MANUALLY ADD YOUR KEY TO THE ACTIVATION DATABASE.   It's just not worth it.    I'm reminded now why this is still the most pirated video game in history as of 2014.

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying I'm reviewing Galactic Adventures instead of regular Spore because I think Galactic Adventures provides the biggest experience, and it's pretty much the same thing as Spore but with the adventures. My opinion here can also be applied to normal Spore.
God, do I love Spore. Waaaaay too much. It's one of my most favorite games of all time, but at the same time, it's brought hate and anger not only upon myself, but upon my close friends.
I know, I need to explain. It would seem that it's an unfair judgment to say this is one of my favorite games considering I only have 33 hours logged on it and I've only had it for a few weeks (at the time I'm writing this review), but I've owned the CD-ROM version since it came out, and I'm pretty sure I've spent hundreds upon hundreds of hours playing it. As someone who's soon to be 16 and grew up with a different era of games, this is one of the biggest games to define my childhood (considering I was about 9 or 10 when it came out). I got addicted to it, and sadly, my friends did, too. Every single friend I've shown Spore to, they got addicted to it, and it became the center of every friendship I had. Sadly, Spore wasn't multiplayer, so I had to constantly watch my friends play Spore when they came over. They weren't open to anything else, just Spore. It became incredibly boring and repetitive, and because of that, many fights broke out between me and my friends, which made me just hate Spore all the more. But at the same time, I loved it. When my friends would leave, I'd have Spore all to myself, and I'd play it constantly until another friend comes over and the cycle repeats. Sadly, I eventually lost my Spore CD, and for the longest time, I was at peace with my friends. We would actually do things together.
That is, until, Spore went on sale a few weeks ago. I remembered loving that game, so I bought it again, hoping my friends forgot about it. I logged into my old Spore account, and surely enough, everything was still there. It was all coming back to me; I couldn't help but shed a tear when I saw my old creations, my childhood. I was a little irritated when playing my old adventures since I was terrible at making them, not to mention I was terrible at spelling, but I saw it more as a joke than something to be embarrassed about. After looking over some old creations, I started a new game on the story mode, and I was instantly hooked again.
And eventually, my friends got hooked again. They saw me playing it, they started playing it again, and I even have some new friends hooked to it. I thought the cycle stopped when I lost the Spore disc, but a cycle can never stop, it always repeats. As of this week, I got into a small argument with my friend over how we should do something else other than Spore, which made me realize this whole thing is getting worse. But at the same time, Spore is more fun than ever. It's the best game ever, it's the worst game ever.
But enough of what I believe makes it so great. From a non-personal standpoint, this game's still something to be enjoyed. The story mode has five stages to it, and each one is unique, which gives it a fresh experience. Each stage is fairly short, but replayable. Not to mention, a bigger variety of choices opens up when you chose to be friendly, neutral, or aggressive in each stage. It changes not only the way you play and the abilities you're given, but also what other think of you, so planning out your choices is necessary. Plus, the fact that you create the creature you play as is really cool. All of the possibilities makes each time you play story mode seem like a unique experience. Outside of creatures, you can also build vehicles, houses, and my favorite, adventures. Playing the adventures was a huge part of my experience playing Spore, and making them was just as fun.
It's pretty hard to look at Spore from a critical standpoint, because for me, there's not too much to say outside of the fact that what it does is really fun. It defined my childhood, and because of that, I've chosen to give it two different reviews: my own personal review, and a review from a critical standpoint.
From a critical standpoint, I would give Spore a 9 out of 10, and I would recommend it to anyone who's a fan of games that offer a creative, unique experience.
However, from a personal standpoint, I would give Spore a perfect 10 out of 10. I just hold it too close to my heart, and I've played it way too much to think it's not perfect.

reviewText: I'm writing this review as a positive outlook on the game, but there as still a few issues. One, the servers are very unstable; you have to re-login everytime after you exit the creator and want to share your creation, two, the game crashes very often, especially when the game accidentally downloads a Creepy and Cute creature, it doesn't even show that you don't have that DLC! There could've been more parts, I've seen Maxis cells have parts that players can't access, which is very bizarre. In addition, I would love to see a sequel of this game; the enhancements, additions, replacements, and removal of issues could be a lot better. I guarantee that if you ask every player that owns Spore, if you asked them if they would like a Spore 2, over 90% would say yes.  Overall, this DLC allows you to install mods, create adventures, I'm glad I chose to get this DLC first. Adventure creating is time-consuming, but it's worth it in the end. That is the end of this review, I highly recommend this DLC and game, and check out my guide on Adventure creating!

reviewText: May be scientifically innacurate regarding evolution theory, but being able to play and evolve a creature on the path to space is very enjoyable.
